definition: variant of 糊裡糊塗|糊里糊涂[hu2 li5 hu2 tu2]
muddled/paste/scorched
paste/cream
Li (surname)

li, ancient measure of length, approx. 500 m/neighborhood/ancient administrative unit of 25 families/(Tw) borough, administrative unit between the township 鎮|镇[zhen4] and neighborhood 鄰|邻[lin2] levels
muddled/paste/scorched
paste/cream
to apply (paint etc)/to smear/to daub/to blot out/to scribble/to scrawl/(literary) mud/street

sentences.english: Otherwise the little helpers might get your wish muddled up.
sentences.chinese: 不然，小助手們可能就糊里糊塗把你聖誕願望搞錯了。

sentences.english: The boss gamme me so many instructions at one time that I got muddled up.
sentences.chinese: 老闆一下子給了我那麼多指示，把我弄得糊里糊塗。

sentences.english: I mooned my way through grade and high school.
sentences.chinese: 我糊里糊塗讀完了五年級和中學。

sentences.english: The boss gave me so many instructions at one time that I got puzzled.
sentences.chinese: 老闆一下子給了我那麼多指示，把我弄得糊里糊塗。

sentences.english: Mary is such a scatterbrain that she always forgets something.
sentences.chinese: 瑪莉糊里糊塗的，她總是忘東忘西。

sentences.english: The answer seems to be as confusing as ever.
sentences.chinese: 至此，我的回答似乎還是讓人感到糊里糊塗。

sentences.english: Despite my confusion, I ascended the mountain.
sentences.chinese: 糊里糊塗中，我開始登山。

sentences.english: He walked numbly into the cemetery.
sentences.chinese: 他糊里糊塗地走進了墓地。

sentences.english: You'd better not muddle me about, but tell me the truth.
sentences.chinese: 你最好別把我弄得糊里糊塗，而是把實情告訴我。

sentences.english: She gave me so many instructions that I got muddled up.
sentences.chinese: 她給了我那麼多指示，把我弄得糊里糊塗。

definition: fair and reasonable (idiom); sensible/standing to reason
to blab/to shoot one's mouth off/to commit a gaffe
to know the score (idiom)/to be well aware of the situation
confused/vague/indistinct/muddle-headed/mixed up/in a daze
to weigh up sb's words and observe their facial expression (idiom)/to discern what sb thinks from his body language
to bring trouble on oneself (idiom)
exactly what one wants
to step down gracefully (humble expression)/to concede defeat/to play second fiddle
clever and quick-witted
to sow dissension (idiom); to drive a wedge between
white lie
to get straight to the point (idiom)
to lose one's cool/to get impatient/unable to remain calm
conventional greeting/polite formula
to have boundless prospects
clever and eloquent (idiom); fluent/having the gift of the gab
